thesis.description: This thesis, which is submitted in part fulfilment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science, has been based upon a petrographic study of a series of thin sections of typical Cornish rocks, which are contained in the Petrographic Collection of McGill University. The writer, not having had the good fortune of visiting the tin deposits, has had to reply mainly on published sources for a great deal of the information included in this work. In this respect he has found the Memoirs of the Geological Survey of England pertaining to this district, particularly valuable and instructive. The writer takes pleasure in expressing his obligations to the members of the staff of the Geological Department of McGill University, who have read portions of the manuscript and offered valuable criticisms and suggestions, both in regard to form and content. [...]
thesis.creator: Wilson, Harold S.
thesis.subject: Geological Sciences.
thesis.title: Geology of the tin deposits of Cornwall.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The three greatest economic problems in bee management are brood diseases, wintering, and swarming. While the first two are important, the subject of swarm control opens up a discussion which generally develops into a lengthy debate. There is a tremendous amount of literature on the subject, advocating various manipulations to subdue this propensity, yet the average beekeeper is groping in the dark for a method that will best suit his needs. The writer's stimulus for investigation, although largely for educational purposes, was also from a mercenary origin. Having seven commercial apiaries consisting of about four hundred oolonies, and also being in charge of the experimental apiaries at the 0.A. College, Guelph, he found himself confronted with the above problem. [...]
thesis.creator: Dyce, Elton James.
thesis.subject: Agriculture.
thesis.title: A study of the swarm control of bees.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: One of the main reasons for the study of gums or slimes produced by micro-organisms in the past has been their industrial importance. Such problems as the viscous fermentations ofbeer and wine, ropiness in milk, and slime in bread, drew the attention of investigators to the possible significance of such abnormalities. While it is true that some fermentations are benefitted by viscocity as in the formation of Dutch "lange-Wei", used as a starter in the manufacture of Edam cheese, of "taettemaelk" (thick milk) of Norway and of "Filmjolk" (stringy milk) of Sweden and Finland, it is generally considered that, for the most part, such fermentations were destructive, and resulted in the spoilage of the product concerned. [...]
thesis.creator: Hamilton, William B.
thesis.subject: Bacteriology.
Azotobacter chroococcum.
thesis.title: Gum production by Azotobacter chroococcum Beijerinck and its physiological significance.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The beginning of agriculture is considered to have marked the dawn of civilization. One would be justified in saying that it marked also the birth of experimental science, for agriculture was indeed the earliest of empirical sciences, and is based on the accumulated wisdom and experience of a hundred centuries of practical experimentation. In r√©cent years agricultural practice has been subjected to critical scientific examination, and, in the majority of cases, it has been found to be in accord with the laws of physics, chemistry, botany, physiology and microbiology. These sciences have served to improve modem agriculture and have succeeded in setting it on a level with other applied and industrial sciences of the day. Microbiological investigation has shown that many common agricultural practices are designed to promote certain beneficiai microbial processes in the soil, and these processes have been submitted in recent years to a great deal of bacteriological experimentation. [...]
thesis.creator: Zoond, Alexander.
thesis.subject: Bacteriology.
Nitrogen -- Fixation.
Azotobacter chroococcum.
Green manuring.
thesis.title: The influence of green manures upon the growth and physiological efficiency of Azotobacter chroococcum.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The motor car unlike the locomotive and the steamship, traces its origin to Continental Europe. It is rather remarkable that England who had played such a prominent part in fostering steam traction, contributed nothing of importance to the early development of internal combustion engines. Nor did her people adopt with readiness the new type of vehicle.But stranger perhaps it is that the United States, now recognized as controlling the world's production, was equally unfruitful. The automobile really owes its inception to thepre-existemce of a cheap and reliable fuel supply. Gasoline, prior to its utilization as a source of power was a little thought-of by-product of crude oil and was used almostexclusively for cleaning purposes and in necessarily small quantities. The potentialities of this hydrocarbon were easily recognizable. Being clean, inexpensive and light in weight, it embodied all the desirable features of coal or wood with practically none of their drawbacks. The new power-plant then was no chance invention, but was the expression of an effort to harness this liquid form of power. [...]
thesis.creator: Aikman, Cecil H.
thesis.subject: Automobile industry and trade -- Canada.
thesis.title: The automobile industry of Canada.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: There is possibly no word in the English la.nguage that is so little understood or appreciated to-day as this word mysticism. It is sometimes used as a word or reproach toward those who speak dogmatical1y or with assurance upon any subject of a speculative nature. Again, it is sometimes applied solely to those who claim to have supernatural experiences and discourse with spirit bodies. On the other hand, it is occasionally applied to all forms of religious experiences and beliefs. In this connection it may be regarded as a term standing for all that is of the highest value in life, or may be regarded as synonymous with superstition. All these views may be locked upon as superficialand due to igorance of the true nature of the mystical experience. [...]
thesis.creator: Armstrong, Charles A.
thesis.subject: Psychology.
thesis.title: The psychology of mysticism.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: In the -"Regulations under the Food and Drugs Act", publ1shed by the Department ot Health of Canada, Butter is defined to be: -the clear, non-rancid product, made by gather1ng in any manner the fat of fresh or ripened milk or cream, preferably pasteur1zed, into a mass, which also contains a small portion of the other milk constituents, with or without salt, and contains not less than 80% of milk fat and not more than 16% of water. It may also contain added colouring matter of harmless character". The standard required by the United States (39) is the same as that of Canada, that is, not less thbn 80% of butterfat and not more than l6% of water. [...]

thesis.description: The Jewish people in Egypt are evidence of the Semitic characteristic of migration. Semitic peoples have always been emigrants, even from the early dawn of history. Possessed with the nomadic tendency they moved steadily forward, settling new lands, and overpowering strange peoples. Perhaps this tendency was heightened by the union upon the Palestinian bridge of the Hittite, the Aramaean and the Egyptian stocks, producing a homogeneous race of people, though their several peculiar characteristics constantly asserted themselves. Nor was this migration tendency confined to the early days of Hebrew history. It has been an integral part of the life of Jewish peoples. Their history constantly bears out this fact. [...]
thesis.creator: Boyes, Watson.
thesis.subject: Oriental Languages.
thesis.title: The light shed by the Jewish-Aramaic papyri of the fifth century B. C. upon contemporary biblical literature.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: An exact, but at the same time concise definition of 'Secondary Stresses' is difficult to enunciate, but in a general way, for one who is familiar with the ordinary methods of designing, the following definition is suggested: "The Secondary Stress at any point in a structure is the difference between the values of the actual stress existing at that point and the theoretical stress for the same point calculated by the usual method of stress analysis, which assumes certain ideal loading and fabricating conditions." [...]
thesis.creator: Campbell, Alexander.
thesis.subject: Civil Engineering.
thesis.title: An investigation of the secondary stresses in a roof truss having unsymmetrical members.

thesis.description: In a thesis which covers a number of dlfferet points in relation to the spleen we may begin with a brief summary of the literature on the organ, which, be it remarked, is very extensive. We find the spleen mentioned in most unlikely places. Astronomers, philosophers and metaphysicists and poets have all sought iaspiration in this "organon pleni mysterii", until we find it clothed in a multi coloured robe redolent with mysticism and possibilities but utterly devoid of truth. Until falr1y reoent times the function of the spleen was amatter of mere conjecture. Aristotle doubted its use. Pliny was of the opinion that it had the property of hindering a man in running, and that its extirpation increased speed. He also thought that it controlled mirth, and that if it were extirpated, laughter fled the patient. [...]
thesis.creator: Cashin, Martin F.
thesis.subject: Spleen.
Perfusion (Physiology)
Physiology.
thesis.title: Perfusion of surviving spleen with particles in suspension.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Work on the distribution of charge and of electric fields in gas discharge tubes has been carried on along various lines since about 1880, three principal methods of experiment being followed, viz: the probe method, cathode ray deflection, and the measurement of the separation of spectral lines in Stark effect photographs. The earliest measurements were made by Hittorf 1; Graham 2, Herz 3, H. A. Wilson 4, and others, all of whom used the probe method. This consisted in placing a wire at various points along the line of discharge, observations of the potential difference between the wire and one electrode giving the distribution of potential throughout the tube. [...]
thesis.creator: Chalk, Mary L.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: Potential distributions in the Crookes dark space and relative intensities of Stark effect components of H-[beta] and He-[lamda].
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Vegetablp oils are glycerides of organic acids and are usually classified according to their power of "setting" or "drying" when spread in thin films exposed to the air on plates of non-absorbent material such as glass. Three main groups are recognized: non-drying oils, e.g. olive oil; semi-drying oils, e. g. cotton-eeed. oil; and drying oils, e. g. linseedoil. It is with drying oils in generall and linseed oil in particular that this paper deals. [...]
thesis.creator: Chataway, Helen D.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The sulphuration of fatty oils.

thesis.description: The rotation at crops is a most important factor in good farm practioe. The discovery by Hellriegel and Wi1farth (7) that leguminous p1ants in symbiotic re1at1on with bacteria secured nitrogen from the air and stored it in nodules on their roots explained the effect that had been observed by many previous investigators, that oertain plants made much stronger growth a¬£ter leguminous crops. We now know from the work done by Russel (11) and others that other forms of soil organisms also increase the supply of nitrogen in thesoi1 when conditions are favorable. The forage crops that are grown for their stems, 1eaves and roots require large quantities of nitrogenous food during their early growth. This can be secured by having them follow leguminous crops and by applying manure rich in nitrogen. The cereal crops that require a larger proportion of phosphates can be placed to advantage following the rank growing forage crops which use up the abundanoe of free nitrates from the clover sod and the farmyard manure. [...]
thesis.creator: Clark, John A.
thesis.subject: Crop rotation.
Agronomy.
thesis.title: A study of the influences of several rotations on yield and cost of producing farm crops.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Efferent Nerves Causing Contraction. Schiff (1867) was the first to show that the stimulation of the splanchnic nerves and of the coeliac ganglion causes contraction of the spleen.Bulgak (1877) found that stimulation of anterior root fibres over a considerable extent of the thoracic cord causes contraction of the spleen by way of the great splanchnic nerve. Roy (1881) introduced the plethysmograph for study of splenic contraction. He observed that the organ is normally subject to regular alternation of volume, in virtue of which it acts as a pump. Schafer and Moore (1896), using Roy's plethysmographic teohnique, were able to confirm and to extend many of Bulgak's results. They found that the muscular tissue of the spleen derives a spinal innervation from a very large number of nerve roots, viz., from the 3rd to the 14th poscoervioal segment in the dog and in the cat. [...]
thesis.creator: Cleland, John G.
thesis.subject: Physiology.
thesis.title: The nervous connections of the spleen.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: THE POLITICO-ECCLESIASTICAL CONDITIONS OF ENGLAND IN THE YEAR 1547. When Henry V111 died in 1547 and young Edward VI ascended the throne, England had undergone a great change touching the final authority in civil and religious questions. The issue was whether the Pope or the King was to be the final authority in the realm. Henry settled the question in the beginning of the second half of his reign and the results were far reaching. Henry had been educated for the Church but upon the death" of his father and brother he married his sister-in-law Catherine of Aragon, and ascended the throne with the brightest of prospects for his future and that of his kingdom. During the first half of his reign, he distinguished himself in the service of the church, and the Pope, in recognition conferred upon him the title of "Defensor Fidei." [...]
thesis.creator: Di Florio, Pasquale.
thesis.subject: History.
thesis.title: Peter Martyr: a study in Italian influence upon theEnglish Reformation principally in the reign of Edward VI .
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: A number of years ago the idea prevailed and was expressed in terms which apparently left little room for doubt, that the area in which wheat could be grown suooessfully could not possibly extend beyond the line whioh now forms the northern boundary of the United States. Today, however, we know as also the rest of the world knows, that the finest quality wheat in the world is produoed north of this boundary, in the three prairie provinoes of Canada, and the area of wheat production is still extending northwards. Within more recent years a belief paralleling that already mentioned existed in regard to the growing of corn. It is but a very short time ago that the belief held that corn oould not be grown successfully as far north as the international boundary. But once again Scienoe has prevailed and has overoome the obstacles set up in her path by Nature, for we have today thousands upon thousands of acres devoted to the production of corn each year in the Canadian Prairie provinces and the acreage is steadily increasing. [...]

thesis.subject: Agronomy,
thesis.title: A comparison of first generation corn hybrids with their parent types.

thesis.description: Attention was first directed to the physiological properties of extracts of the pituitary gland by Oliver and Schafer (1) in 1895. These authors injected an aqueous extract of the whole gland into an anaesthetized animal and obtained a rise in blood pressure. Later, in 1898, Howell (2) localized this pressor activity in the posterior lobe of the gland. Subsequent investigations have shown that extracts of the posterior lobe have physiological activities which manifest themselves on the cardio-vascular, renal, smooth muscle, and glandular structures of the body. The most important of these activities are generally held to be thepressor, oxytocic, and renal actions, or, as the latter is sometimes termed, diuretic-antidiuretic. As the experiments reported in this paper deal with the unity or multiplicity of the constituents responsible for these three activities, a resume' of the history and present state of our knowledge concerning them is given below. [...]
thesis.creator: Draper, William B.
thesis.subject: Pharmacology.
thesis.title: The unity or multiplicity of the autacoids responsible for the pressor, oxytocic, and renal activities of the posterior lobe of the pituitary gland.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This thesis is written in the department of English literature; therefore I have refrained from discussion of the work of the French-Canadians, as dramatists or as players. I have not given the biographical facts of writers resident in Canada, but only of those who have left their home land and are too frequently considered natives of other countries. I do not presume to speak with finality. After all, in drama as well as in all forms of literature, time is the supreme test, and either fortunately or unfortunately, a graduate student does not belong to that aristocracy of time, by which a work of art is ultimately judged. Canada has been so busy building her house, hewing it, as it were from a wilderness, that she has had little time to decorate it. Statements are frequently made, however, that Canada has produced neither playwright, play nor player. This is not justified by the facts. What I have tried to do in this discussion, is to examine that statement and to disprove it, by evidence, some of which has been exceedingly difficult to obtain. [...]
thesis.creator: Edwards, Margaret C.
thesis.subject: English.
thesis.title: Canadian drama, dramatists, and players.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: General statement: The district discussed in this paper is distinguished from the rest of the province not only by a difference of physical features, but also by the method of survey. Being the first part of south-eastern Quebec to be surveyed after the English manner, it was divided into counties, townships, ranges and lots instead of into seigniories, and parishes, according to the custom that prevailed during the French rule in Canada. Thus the distr is generally known as the "Eastern Townships." These early surveyors instead of dividing the district symmetrically into rectangular areas, split up the oountry in a most complicated, and irregular manner. Then, as if not satisfied with the puzale already created, they proceeded to number the ranges and lots in a still less systematic manner. The compiling of maps, particularly on small scale, is thus rendered slow and tedious. [...]
thesis.creator: Ellis, David H.
thesis.subject: Geology & Mineralogy.
thesis.title: A study of the genesis of the copper and other ores of the Eastern Townships of Quebec.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The productive coal fields of Nova Scotia are confined almost entirely to four counties; Cape Breton (north and south), Inverness, Cumberland (Springhill and the Joggins), and Pictou. Of the total coal production, however, more than eighty-five per cent comes from Cape Breton, Pictou, and Springhill. (l) "The Sydney coal field, the largest and most valuable in Nova Scotia, "says Colonel Walter Herd, Chief Mining Engineer of the British Empire Steel Corporation, (2) "is situated on the north east coast of Cape Breton, extendingfrom Mira Bay on the south to Cape Dauphin on the north, a distance of thirty miles, and having a general dip north and east under the sea". Sydney Harbour cuts off direct communication between the northern area, around Sydney Mines and the larger part of the coal field to the south east. [...]
thesis.creator: Forsey, Eugene Alfred.
thesis.subject: Economics & Political Science.
Coal trade -- Nova Scotia.
thesis.title: Economic and social aspects of the Nova Scotia coal industry.

degree.name: Master of Arts
degree.discipline: Department of Economics and Political Science

thesis.description: Until the last few years, Canada has never devoted much attention to the development of markets for her surplus creamery butter. Although this product has been exported in varying quantities since the introduction of mechanical refrigeration on steamships in 1897, the period of rapid growth prior to the war steadily reduced the volume available for export, until in 1913 this country imported six times as much as she exported. More recently, there has been a decided increase in butter production, not only in Ontario and Quebec, but also in the three Prairie Provinces. In the latter, the phenomenal growth of the dairy industry can be attributed largely to the development of a system of mixed farming, as a result of the poor returns from grain-growing after 1920. Thus these provinces, which not long ago imported butter, now manufacture nearly as much as is made in Ontario. Unlike the latter province, these provinces have few industrial centres to provide a home market, and are forced to seek a market for any surplus farther afield. [...]
thesis.creator: Johns, Cyril Kay.
thesis.subject: Bacteriology.
Butter -- Analysis.
thesis.title: A rapid method for the quantitative determination of moulds and yeasts in creamery butter.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The purpose or this, investigation was first, to clear up certain obscure anatomical points with reference to the vascular arrangements of the spleen,and finally to study its mechanism of phagocytosis.HISTORICAL. Our knowledge of the anatomy ot the sp1een dates, from Malpighi (1686) who discovered in the spleen of the ox, the lymph fo11ic1es which bear his name and the stigmata or openings in the venous sinuses. Ten years later, Ruysch (1.696) found that the terminal arteries of the human spleen are long and straight and do not anastomose. He called them, penicil1i, from their resemblance to pencils or fine brushes. [...]
